Title: Minimum Viable AIMS: ISO 42001 Required Documentation Artifacts for Beginners
Abstract: Experimenting with LLMs is fun until someone asks: who approved this, mwhat changed, what data was used, and can we explain it? Let's demystify "Minimum Viable AIMS": ISO 42001 documentation artifacts that make your organization’s AI management system audit-ready.

Title: Orchestrating Agentic State Machines with LangGraph: Learnings from Automating clinical documentation
Abstract:
Medical documentation continues to be one of the biggest productivity bottlenecks in healthcare. In this hands-on workshop, participants will learn how to design and deploy an agentic AI medical scribe that transforms real or simulated doctor–patient conversations into structured SOAP (Subjective, Objective, Assessment, Plan) notes.

Using LangGraph, we’ll build a dynamic, multi-agent system where each node performs a specialized task and communicates through a shared memory graph:

Transcription Agent - converts clinical dialogue into text using a speech-to-text model.

Information Extraction Agent - identifies key clinical entities such as symptoms, vitals, and diagnoses.

Summarization Agent - generates structured SOAP notes and validates internal consistency through a self-reflective loop.


Attendees will see how LangGraph enables state-aware orchestration and real-time coordination between these agents, how to integrate retrieval grounding using clinical ontologies (ICD-10, SNOMED), and how to measure performance with F1, ROUGE-L, and readability metrics.

By the end, participants will deploy a lightweight, production-ready prototype that demonstrates how agentic workflows can automate time-consuming documentation tasks, while remaining transparent, auditable, and compliant.

Title: Governing Data Sovereignty in Distributed Multi-Cloud Machine Learning Systems
Abstract: Discover how to build compliant, scalable multi-cloud ML systems amid rapidly evolving global data sovereignty laws. Learn where governance breaks down, what regulators expect next, and how sovereign cloud, zero-trust, and automation can future-proof ML deployments.

JobTitle1: Business Intelligence Engineer, AMZL Automation Planning
Company1: Business Intel Engineer I at Amazon
Title: Machine Learning as the Intelligence Layer for Adaptive, Self-Optimizing Systems
Abstract: Discover how machine learning becomes the intelligence layer for automation enabling adaptive, self-healing systems that boost throughput, cut downtime, and transform operations. Learn practical frameworks to deploy scalable, ML-driven industrial intelligence.

Title: Next-Generation AI Agents: Orchestrating Technological Evolution
Abstract: AI is evolving from isolated models to autonomous agents that interact with complex environments. Aleksandr Viatkin will explain how next-generation AI agents, inspired by principles from neuroscience and active inference, can be orchestrated to solve real-world tasks efficiently and adaptively. Attendees will learn how these approaches can reduce computational overhead, improve interpretability, and scale AI beyond traditional deep learning architectures.

Title: Building Secure Backend Services with AI Agents
Abstract: As AI agents become part of everyday engineering, building secure backend systems is more critical than ever. Marat Kenzhebulatov will show how to integrate AI agents safely in security-critical workflows, from code review and threat modeling to automated checks, without exposing sensitive data. Attendees will leave with practical guidelines, lightweight patterns, and a checklist for leveraging AI agents while maintaining real-world security and compliance.

Title: Explainable Hybrid RAG–LLM Framework for Dynamic Supplier Risk Intelligence
Abstract: Discover how an explainable hybrid RAG–LLM system transforms supplier risk intelligence by fusing ERP data with real-time external signals. Learn to detect hidden financial, compliance, and ESG risks faster with transparent, auditable AI built for global supply chains.

Title: LLM Agents for Site Reliability: Production-Safe Architectures for AI-Powered Incident Response
Abstract: LLMs can revolutionize incident response—but only with proper guardrails. Discover a production-safe architecture where AI agents accelerate root cause analysis, generate hypotheses, and suggest mitigations while humans keep decision authority. Build trust, not risk.

Title: Maximizing Credit Card Profitability with Machine Learning–Driven CLV
Abstract: From raw transactions to real profit: discover how ML-driven CLV models help credit card teams optimize approvals, credit lines, and engagement while balancing growth and risk.

Title: The Role of Machine Learning in Today’s Payment Ecosystems
Abstract: The Role of Machine Learning in Today’s Payment Ecosystems covers how machine learning is used across modern payment platforms to support intelligent transaction processing, operational efficiency, and system adaptability. The session explains where machine learning fits within payment flows.

Title: System-Level Experimentation at Scale: Pricing, Supply, A/B and Switchback Testing in FoodTech
Abstract: Traditional A/B tests often fail in complex platforms when interventions like dynamic pricing affect the entire ecosystem, causing supply constraints and cross-user effects. Sergei Nasibian will introduce Switchback testing, a time-based alternative to user-level randomization that enables reliable system-level experimentation. Using real-world FoodTech examples, he will show how this framework optimizes metrics like Cost Per Order, courier efficiency, and order growth while aligning with operations and growth strategy.

Title: Data-Driven Structural Intelligence for Telecom Towers in the 5G Era
Abstract: From load combinations to digital twins, this talk bridges classical structural engineering with modern data analytics. Discover how structured engineering data and ML-ready workflows help future-proof telecom towers at scale.

Title: Applying Machine Learning to Performance Optimization in High-Volume Transaction Systems
Abstract: What if your transaction systems could predict performance issues before they happen? Learn how machine learning models use real-time telemetry to optimize scaling, reduce latency, and build self-adapting microservice platforms for high-volume workloads.

Title: Beyond Surveys: Real-Time User Satisfaction Prediction with LLMs and Telemetry
Abstract: Stop waiting for surveys! Learn to predict user satisfaction in real time by fusing LLMs with behavioral telemetry. We'll explore a multi-modal AI framework that identifies "Detractors" with 86% accuracy, enables proactive interventions, and delivers sub-100ms inference with SHAP explainability.
Slides: Abhinay Kumar Reddy Seella - Conf42 Machine Learning 2026.pdf

Title: Unifying Online and Offline Worlds: A Machine-Learning Framework for Cross-Channel Attribution and Marketing ROI
Abstract: Discover how machine learning can finally connect digital and physical customer journeys. Learn a practical, scalable framework for cross-channel attribution that boosts ROI, improves decisions, and reveals insights no single channel can show.

Title: Making recommendations explainable
Abstract: How we turned a black-box recommender into a traceable, explainable ranking system in production: full recsys pipeline, per-user recommendation traces, and dashboards that product, safety and ML teams actually use.

Title: Beyond Send-Time Optimization: From Prediction to AI-Driven Decisioning in B2C Marketing
Abstract:
Send-time optimization has traditionally been treated as a prediction problem—using historical data to determine when customers are most likely to engage. While effective in simpler environments, this approach falls short in today’s B2C landscape, where customers receive multiple messages across channels, campaigns compete for attention, and engagement is constrained by fatigue, regulations, and business priorities. In this context, selecting the “best” send time is no longer just a modeling task, but a decision-making challenge.

This session reframes send-time optimization as an AI-driven decision system that combines machine learning and artificial intelligence in complementary ways. Machine learning provides predictive signals such as engagement likelihood and time-based patterns, while AI adds reasoning, orchestration, and goal awareness—resolving tradeoffs between urgency, relevance, frequency, and customer experience in real time.
Slides: Murthy Chandrapaty & Chakravarthy Kalva - Conf42 Machine Learning 2026.pdf

Title: The AI Product Spec: A Hands-On Tutorial for Defining and Scoping Recommendation Systems
Abstract: This topic allows me to share my direct, practical experience in a structured way that provides tangible skills for the audience, fully in line with the hands-on tutorial format.

Title: Zero Service Desk: Applying Machine Learning for Autonomous IT Support
Abstract: What if IT support could fix issues before users report them? Learn how machine learning, conversational AI, and automation enable a Zero Service Desk eliminating tickets, predicting incidents, and delivering autonomous, self-service IT at scale.

Title: ML-Powered IoT: From Warehouse Data to Production Intelligence in Real Time
Abstract: Discover how to deploy production ML models that turn messy IoT warehouse data into real-time intelligence. Learn the MLOps, feature engineering, and deployment strategies that actually work at scale

Title: Transforming Inventory Forecasting with Production ML
Abstract:
Inventory forecasting is a high impact problem where small improvements can unlock significant operational gains. In this session, we’ll explore how production grade machine learning can be used to move beyond static forecasts and spreadsheets toward adaptive, data driven inventory decisions.

We’ll walk through how real world demand signals, feature engineering, and continuous model retraining come together in a production ML system. The talk will focus on practical lessons learned deploying and operating forecasting models at scale, including data quality challenges, model drift, and integration with existing supply chain workflows.

Attendees will leave with a concrete understanding of what it takes to turn inventory forecasting from an analytical exercise into a reliable production ML capability.

Title: Stop Failures Before They Happen: Gradient Boosting for Perfect Flows
Abstract: Predicting failures before they happen saves time and resources! Running Prefect workflows for JPMC’s X-Margin team is time- and resource-intensive, and failures can go unnoticed until after the calculation. Pavel will explain how training a gradient boosting (XGBoost) model on workflow metadata—inputs, run parameters, and code revisions—enables the system to predict failures in advance. Developers are then alerted instantly, allowing them to fix problems early, saving time, reducing costs, and improving reliability.

Title: Stop Failures Before They Happen: Gradient Boosting for Perfect Flows
Abstract: Learn how automation transforms compliance from a bottleneck into a strategic advantage for ML-driven SaaS. This talk reveals practical, data-backed methods to scale securely, reduce engineering overhead, and build sustainable, high-trust platforms powered by continuous compliance.

Title: From Experiment to Enterprise: Building Scalable, Observable MLOps Systems on Google Cloud
Abstract: Shipping ML is harder than training it. Learn how to move models from notebooks to reliable production with a scalable, observable MLOps framework on Google Cloud covering real-time, batch, and streaming inference, drift detection, CI/CD, and retraining.

Title: From ML Pilots to Production: An AI Readiness Blueprint for Enterprises
Abstract: Why do most ML pilots fail to scale? It’s not the models it’s readiness. Learn a practical blueprint to stop pilot sprawl, align teams, and build the data, governance, and infrastructure foundations required to move machine learning into production with confidence.

Title: Why Good Models Fail After Deployment
Abstract: Great models don’t usually fail because they’re wrong - they fail because the world changes after they’re deployed. This talk explains why strong offline performance is often a poor predictor of real-world success, and how feedback loops, biased data, and misaligned metrics quietly break machine learning systems in production. Learn how to build systems that survive the real world!

Title: Taming Data Skew in Production ML Pipelines: Practical Apache Spark Optimization Techniques
Abstract: Your ML models train slowly because of data skew, not bad code. Learn three proven Spark optimization techniques that cut pipeline times by 40% and reduce costs—battle-tested in production at scale.

JobTitle1: Director of Cloud Operations at SAP
Title: From Reliable Models to Resilient ML Platforms: Designing Secure, Highly Available Infrastructure for Production Machine Learning
Abstract: Production ML fails without resilient infrastructure. Learn how real-world teams redesigned compute platforms using HA, DR, and Zero Trust to keep training, inference, and data pipelines secure, available, and reliable at scale.

Title: Protecting PHI in Machine Learning Development Environments
Abstract: Machine learning in healthcare is exploding, but PHI exposure in development environments is driving massive breaches and costs. This talk delivers real data, proven controls, and a practical roadmap to secure ML pipelines without slowing innovation.

Title: IAM and Privileged Access Foundations for Secure Enterprise ML Platforms
Abstract: Machine learning platforms are only as secure as the identities behind them. Learn how IAM and Privileged Access Management protect data, models, and pipelines while enabling compliance, visibility, and control across modern enterprise environments.

JobTitle1: Head of Third Party Risk Management, Senior Manager ERM
Title: Machine Learning–Driven Third-Party Risk Management at Scale
Abstract: From unstructured documents to early-warning signals, discover how machine learning reshapes third-party risk management into a scalable, data-driven intelligence system built for complex ecosystems.
Slides: Sagar Sudhir Behere - Conf42 Machine Learning 2026.pdf

Title: Machine Learning–Driven Compliance Engines for Zero Trust Security
Abstract: Static compliance policies can’t keep up with Zero Trust. Learn how machine learning enables real-time, adaptive compliance by continuously learning from user behavior, endpoint telemetry, and threat intelligence turning compliance into an intelligent security control.
Slides: Sudheer Kumar Aluvala - Conf42 Machine Learning 2026.pdf

Title: Building GenAI That Doesn't Cost the Earth
Abstract: AI's carbon footprint is exploding—but it doesn't have to. Discover how to slash your generative AI workloads' environmental impact by up to 99% on AWS while cutting costs. Practical techniques you can implement today.

Title: Towards Unified Perception: End-to-End Scene Understanding Models for Autonomous Driving
Abstract: Discover how unified perception models are replacing fragmented AV pipelines. Learn how next-gen fusion architectures deliver faster, smarter, end-to-end scene understanding for safer autonomous driving.
Slides: Sowmiya Narayanan Govindaraj - Conf42 Machine Learning 2026.pdf

Title: AI-Driven Engineering Quality: How We Use Machine Learning to Predict Delivery Time and Improve Code Reliability
Abstract: Shipping breaks when planning is guesswork. I’ll show a production ML system that scores pull requests for risk, estimates delivery time before coding starts, and flags bottlenecks, using repo metadata, AST features, test/CI signals, and LLM-based code smells, fully integrated into CI.
